snippet: Government watchdogs say that the rule could disenfranchise tens of thousands of New Yorkers who will discover next year that they cannot vote in the election that could determine the next mayor.
abstract: Government watchdogs say that New York State's tough eligibility rules for voting in party primaries could keep tens of thousands of New York City residents from voting in the 2013 mayoral primary; under state law, anyone who wants to vote in the 2013 Democratic mayor primary--and all of the anticipated major candidates are Democrats--but is not affiliated with a party, or wants to switch parties, must take action by October 12, 2012.
lead_paragraph: Government watchdogs say that the rule could disenfranchise tens of thousands of New Yorkers who will discover next year that they cannot vote in the election that could determine the next mayor.

headline.seo: 2013 New York Primary Voting Requires Any Party Changes by Oct. 12
headline.main: 2013 New York Primary Voting Requires Any Party Changes by Oct. 12
headline.print_headline: Deadline Is Next Week for Voters to Change Party Affiliation for 2013 Citywide Primaries
